nodes.text: Government debt (external or internal) changes the long-run competitive equilibrium in a neoclassical growth model and thus affects the lifetime utility of a representative individual

Model assumptions: discrete time, infinite horizon, identical two-period lived individuals, no bequests, constant returns to scale production function F(K,L), no depreciation, population grows at rate n, utility U(c1,c2)

Central planner can choose Golden Age Paths with constant capital-labor ratio k; Golden Rule choice sets marginal product of capital equal to growth rate, f'(k)=n, maximizing per capita lifetime consumption

Competitive equilibrium is determined by individual lifetime saving decisions given wages and market interest rates where interest equals marginal product of capital r=f'(k); this equilibrium can be dynamically inefficient if r differs from n

Method: introduce government that issues one-period debt with constant debt-labor ratios, finances interest via lump-sum taxes on young, consider separately externally held debt and internally held debt and compare long-run equilibria
Individual optimization: given wage w and interest r an individual solves U(c1,c2) subject to budget constraint c1+c2/(1+r)=w, yielding saving s(w,r) and first order condition equating marginal rates

Capital market equilibrium: aggregate saving S=sum s(w,r) equals K_{t+1}, and equilibrium condition links r_{t+1} to prior period wage via r_{t+1}=f'(s(w_t,r_{t+1})/(1+n)) producing a mapping whose stability matters for comparative statics

Result: external debt affects the domestic economy only through taxes needed to finance interest not covered by new debt and through the induced change in equilibrium (w,r); in the normal efficient case (r>n) external debt reduces long-run individual utility

Result: internal debt affects supply side via taxes like external debt and also affects demand side because government borrows domestically substituting government debt for physical capital in private portfolios, further reducing the capital stock and output

Result: internal debt lowers long-run individual utility in the normal efficient case (r>n) and may raise or lower utility in the dynamically inefficient case (r<n) because changes in r relative to n can improve or worsen allocation

Claim: the sign of welfare effects from either debt depends on whether the competitive equilibrium interest rate is above or below the population growth rate n; movements of r away from n reduce welfare in the efficient case and may increase it in the inefficient case
Method/assumption: debt is one-period maturity, interest paid at current rate, debt-labor ratios held constant by rolling over debt, taxes are lump-sum on the young; this isolates long-run effects

Claim: swapping external for internal debt (issuing internal to retire external) raises the equilibrium interest rate and, in the efficient case, unambiguously lowers long-run individual utility; in the inefficient case the welfare sign is ambiguous

Explanation/Evidence: mechanisms decomposed into (a) tax effects reducing disposable lifetime consumption and savings, (b) reduced capital stock from substitution of debt for capital, and (c) changes in factor prices (w and r) that alter allocation and utility; algebraic derivations and diagrams illustrate these channels

Limitations: results rely on assumptions of no depreciation, no bequests, lump-sum taxation, one-period debt, perfect certainty, and constant debt-labor ratios; alternative assumptions (appendices) can reverse some comparative statics

Conclusion: taxes required to finance internal and external debt have similar incidence on taxpayers, but internal debt typically has a larger adverse long-run effect because it also crowds out physical capital; welfare implications depend on r relative to n
